revision.text:
[[Image:Albany Institute of History and Art Pano.jpg|thumb|350px|The [[Albany Institute of History and Art]] in [[Albany, New York|Albany]]]] '''Culture in [[New York (state)|New York]]'s [[Capital District, New York|Capital District]]''', also known as the [[Albany, New York|Albany]] metropolitan area, stretches back to the 17th century. The area has seen prominent historical events, interesting artistic creations, and unique contributions to the [[culture of the United States]]. The largest city in the area, Albany, consistently ranks high on lists of top cities/metro areas for culture, such as being 23rd in the book ''Cities Ranked & Rated''.<ref>{{cite web | title = America's Top Cities for Culture | url = http://www.move.com/new-homes/real-estate-news/the-top-10-cultural-cities.aspx | publisher = Move, Inc. | accessdate = 2009-06-04}}</ref> The Albany-Schenectady-Troy metro area ranked 12th among large metro areas, and Glens Falls ranked 12th among the small metro areas, in Sperling's Best Places,<ref name=Techvalley>{{cite web|url=http://www.techvalley.org/Pages/News%20_%20Events/National%20Recognition.html |title=New York's Tech Valley: National Recognition |publisher=Tech Valley Chamber Coalition |accessdate=2009-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724231207/http://techvalley.org/Pages/News%20_%20Events/National%20Recognition.html |archivedate=2008-07-24 |df= }}</ref> and Expansion Management (a monthly business magazine) gave the Albany-Schenectady-Troy area five Stars, its highest ranking, for quality of life features.<ref name=Techvalley/>
==Museums== [[Image:Saratoga-tower.jpg|thumb|left|Saratoga Monument in [[Saratoga National Historical Park]]]] The Capital District has many historical sites and museums covering a wide range of topics and time periods. The [[Albany Institute of History and Art]] founded in 1791 is one of the oldest museums in the nation,<ref>[http://www.albanyinstitute.org/HTML/history.htm The History of the Albany Institute of History from the 1700s to the Present<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229200707/http://www.albanyinstitute.org/HTML/history.htm |date=2012-02-29 }}</ref> and the [[New York State Museum]] is the oldest and largest state museum in the nation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/membership/ |title=Support the New York State Museum |publisher=New York State Museum |accessdate=2009-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090603205328/http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/membership/ |archivedate=2009-06-03 |df= }}</ref> Many of the museums are historical sites themselves, such as Cherry Hill, the [[Ten Broeck Mansion]], and the [[Schuyler Mansion]] in Albany, the Pruyn House in [[Colonie, New York|Colonie]], [[Old Fort Johnson]] in [[Fort Johnson, New York|Fort Johnson]], and the [[Hart-Cluett Mansion]] in [[Troy, New York|Troy]]. The [[Crailo State Historic Site]] in the city of [[Rensselaer, New York|Rensselaer]] was built in the early 18th century and is a museum of colonial [[New Netherland]] history.<ref>{{cite web | title = Crailo State Historic Site | publisher = New York State Office of Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation | url = http://nysparks.state.ny.us/sites/info.asp?siteID=7 | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref> Other historical sites and museums chronicle historic events of national importance from the Revolutionary War such as the [[Saratoga National Historical Park]] in [[Saratoga County, New York|Saratoga County]] and the [[Bennington Battlefield State Historic Site]] in [[Rensselaer County, New York|Rensselaer]].
[[The Children's Museum of Science and Technology]] (The Junior Museum) in [[North Greenbush, New York|North Greenbush]], the [[Burden Iron Works]] in Troy, and the [[Schenectady Museum]] in [[Schenectady, New York|Schenectady]] are three museums that are focused on the technological and scientific history of the region. The Schenectady Museum also has a [[planetarium]], as does the Albany Heritage Area Visitors Center in Albany. Though the [[Dudley Observatory]], in Schenectady, is no longer a working observatory it still remains the oldest independent organization in the United States supporting astronomy research and has one of the finest astronomy libraries in world.<ref name=JustCR>{{cite web | title = Just the Capital Region.com | publisher = Just the Capital Region | accessdate = 2009-11-24 | url = http://www.justthecapitalregion.com/attractions.htm}}</ref>
Some museums in the area cover a specific topic such as the [[National Bottle Museum]] in [[Ballston Spa, New York|Ballston Spa]], or the Throop Drug Store Museum at the [[Albany College of Pharmacy]]. The [[Empire State Aerosciences Museum]] in [[Glenville, New York|Glenville]], which in addition to air and space exhibits has the most extensive aviation library in New York.<ref>{{cite web | title = Empire State Aerosciences Museum | url = http://www.esam.org/ | publisher = Empire State Aerosciences Museum | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref> In Saratoga Springs is the [[Saratoga Automobile Museum]] covering the historical, technological, social, and economic impact of the automobile.<ref name=JustCR/> Some of the museums in the region are unique, such as the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]] in [[Amsterdam, New York|Amsterdam]], it is the only brick-and-mortar Hall of Fame for that sport.<ref>{{cite web | title = Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum Homepage | publisher = Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum | url = http://www.pwhf.org/ | accessdate = 2009-06-09}}</ref> The [[National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame]] in [[Saratoga Springs, New York|Saratoga Springs]] is the only museum in the United States dedicated to American professional dance.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Museum of Dance: History |url=http://www.dancemuseum.org/nmd/about.htm |publisher=National Museum of Dance |accessdate=2009-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527185028/http://www.dancemuseum.org/nmd/about.htm |archivedate=May 27, 2009 }}</ref>
The Capital District has many museums that cover the history of specific racial, ethnic, or religious groups. The [[Iroquois Indian Museum]] in Schoharie County documents the history and culture of the original inhabitants of the Capital District;<ref name=JustCR/> while the [[Irish American Heritage Museum]] in Downtown Albany is the only museum dealing with Irish heritage in the United States.<ref>{{cite news|title=Irish heritage museum is moving to Albany |publisher=Hearst Corporation|newspaper=Albany Times Union|author=Grondahl, Paul|date=2011-04-25|accessdate=2011-04-25|url=http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Irish-heritage-museum-is-moving-to-Albany-1350785.php}}</ref> The [[Shaker Museum and Library|Shaker Museum ]] in [[Old Chatham, New York]], formerly called Shaker Museum and Library, and the [[Watervliet Shaker Historic District]] in Colonie deal with the religious group of Shakers and their impact on the region; Shaker Museum {{pipe}} Mount Lebanon manages New Lebanon, the first organized and structured Shaker village, while the Watervliet site which the Shaker Heritage Society manages was the first place Shakers settled in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | title = Shaker Heritage Society Homepage | publisher = Shaker Heritage Society | url = http://www.shakerheritage.org/ | accessdate = 2009-05-30}}</ref>
There are also many places of interest to learn about the natural landscape of the Capital District, such as [[Howe Caverns]] in [[Schoharie (town), New York|Schoharie]] and the [[Albany Pine Bush]] Discovery Center in Albany. Lester Park in [[Greenfield, New York|Greenfield]], is a site owned by the New York State Museum, it is a 490 million year old fossil seafloor.<ref>{{cite web | title = Lester Park | publisher = New York State Museum | url = http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/exhibits/longterm/lesterpark/ | accessdate = 2009-05-30 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090604155401/http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/exhibits/longterm/lesterpark/# | archive-date = 2009-06-04 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
The [[USS Slater (DE-766)]], the only escort destroyer from [[World War II]] still afloat,<ref>{{cite web | title = A city's character is up to residents to decide | publisher = Albany Times Union | author = Catherine Hedgeman | accessdate = 2009-06-14 | date = June 14, 2009 | url = http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=810003&category=BUSINESS}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and a reconstruction of Henry Hudson's ''[[Half Moon (ship)|Half Moon]]'' are docked at Albany as floating museums.
==Art== [[Image:View of Hudson and Catskills from Olana.jpg|thumb|Views like this from [[Olana State Historic Site|Olana]] inspired [[Frederic Edwin Church]], of the [[Hudson River School]]]] There are several art galleries of different genres in the Capital District; most are galleries featuring work by local artists. Some have multimedia presentations and classes for locals, such as the Arts Center of the Capital Region in Troy, and the [[Albany Center Gallery]] in downtown Albany, which exhibits works by local artists within a {{convert|100|mi|km|adj=on}} radius of that city.<ref>{{cite web | title = About Us | publisher = Albany Center Gallery | accessdate = 2009-11-25 | url = http://www.albanycentergallery.org/about/}}</ref> The [[Arkell Museum]] in [[Canajoharie (village), New York|Canajoharie]] features American artists such as [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], along with history of the [[Mohawk Valley]]. The [[Empire State Plaza]] in Albany has one of the most important state collections of modern art in the nation.<ref>{{cite web | title = Empire State Plaza Art Collection | publisher = New York State Office of General Services | accessdate = July 24, 2012 | url = http://ogs.ny.gov/ESP/CT/Art.asp | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120822011847/http://ogs.ny.gov/ESP/CT/Art.asp# | archive-date = 2012-08-22 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> [[Yaddo]] in Saratoga Springs and the [[Olana State Historic Site]] in [[Greenport, Columbia County, New York|Greenport]], have natural and architectural works of art and have been used by artists of landscapes such as those of the [[Hudson River School]]. [[The Hyde Collection]] in [[Glens Falls, New York|Glens Falls]] is more of a formal art museum and includes works by [[Botticelli]], [[Degas]], [[Picasso]], [[Raphael]], [[Rembrandt]], [[Renoir]], and [[Van Gogh]].<ref>{{cite web | title = The Hyde Collection | url = http://www.hydecollection.org/ | publisher = The Hyde Collection | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref>
Several of the area's colleges and universities have art museums open to the public displaying art produced locally, nationally, and internationally. These include the Esther Massry Gallery at The College of Saint Rose, [[Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery]] at [[Skidmore College]]; the [[University at Albany, SUNY#University Art Museum|University Art Museum]] at the [[University at Albany, SUNY]]; and the Opalka Gallery at the [[Sage College of Albany]].
==Performing arts== [[File:PalaceTheater.JPG|thumb|The [[Palace Theatre (Albany, New York)|Palace Theatre]] in Albany]] The Capital District is home to many venues for the performing arts, some very old and some very new. Some are owned by municipalities or the state, such as the [[Times Union Center]] (owned by Albany County), the [[Palace Theatre (Albany)|Palace Theatre]] (owned by the city of Albany), or the [[Saratoga Performing Arts Center]] (SPAC) and [[the Egg (building)|the Egg]] (both owned by the state of New York).
The Times Union Center is the largest venue, originally called the Knickerbocker Arena. It opened on January 30, 1990 with a performance by [[Frank Sinatra]].<ref>"Times Union enters a new arena". Carol DeMare. ''[[Times Union (Albany)|Times Union]]''. May 5, 2006</ref> In 1996, [[The Grateful Dead]] released a concert album from their March 1990 performances titled ''[[Dozin' at the Knick]]''.<ref>[http://www.dead101.com/1045.htm Dozin' at the Knick<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Some of the venues, such as [[Proctor's Theatre (Schenectady, New York)|Proctor's Theatre]] in Schenectady and the Palace Theatre in Albany are quite old and started off in the days of [[vaudeville]]. Proctor's and the Palace have evolved into hosting dance, ballet, opera, symphony orchestra, and contemporary music performances such as Proctor's hosting of [[Mariah Carey]]'s filming of her 1993 Thanksgiving NBC Special.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allmariahcarey.com/Videos/thanksgiving-nbc-special.html |title=Thanksgiving NBC Special (1993) |accessdate=2009-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009161812/http://allmariahcarey.com/Videos/thanksgiving-nbc-special.html |archivedate=October 9, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.proctors.org/about | title = A history of Proctors | publisher = Proctor's Theatre | accessdate = 2009-05-30}}</ref> The [[Cohoes Music Hall]], the WAMC's Performing Arts Center (The Linda) in Albany, and the [[Troy Savings Bank|Troy Savings Bank Music Hall]] are three smaller venues also in buildings as old as Proctor's and the Palace.
The Egg in Albany and SPAC in Saratoga Springs are newer venues for concerts, ballet, and orchestra performances both constructed during [[Nelson Rockefeller]]'s tenure as [[governor of New York]]. In addition to outside acts performing in the region, there are local ones as well. The [[Albany Symphony Orchestra]] performs at the Palace and the Troy Savings Bank Music Hall, among other local venues, and a few outside the region as well. The Capital Repertory Theater in Albany and the New York State Theatre Institute (NYSTI) in Troy are local groups with their own performing space. Many local colleges have performing arts spaces as well; one of the newest and most sophisticated is the [[Experimental Media and Performing Arts Center]] (EMPAC) at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] (RPI) in Troy.
==Festivals== [[File:KingFountainWashingtonParkAlbany.jpg|thumb|The King Fountain in [[Washington Park Historic District (Albany, New York)|Washington Park]] in Albany during the [[Tulip Festival (Albany, New York)|Tulip Fest]]]] One of the largest events in the Capital District is the [[Tulip Festival (Albany, New York)|Tulip Fest]] held in Albany every spring at [[Washington Park Historic District (Albany, New York)|Washington Park]]. The tradition stems from when Mayor [[Erastus Corning 2nd]] got a city ordinance passed declaring the [[tulip]] as Albany's official flower on July 1, 1948. In addition, he sent a request to Queen [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands]] to name a variety as Albany's tulip. On July 11, 1948 her reply was "Her Majesty gladly accepts the invitation to designate a tulip as the official flower of Albany." She picked the variety "Orange Wonder", a bronzy orange shaded scarlet. The first Tulip Fest was celebrated the next year on May 14, 1949 with opening ceremonies still carried on today as tradition, such as the sweeping of State Street and the crowning of a Tulip Queen.<ref>{{cite web | title = Albany Tulip Queen | publisher = Albany Tulip Queen.com | accessdate = 2009-06-07 | url = http://www.albanytulipqueen.com/}}</ref> The [[African-American]] tradition of [[Pinkster]]fest, whose origins are traced back even further to Dutch festivities, was later incorporated into the Tulip Fest.
The largest [[Flag Day (United States)|Flag Day]] parade is held every year in Troy. The 42nd annual parade in 2009 is along a two-mile-long route.<ref>{{cite web |title=Troy, NY Flag Day Parade |publisher=City of Troy |url=http://www.troyny.gov/visittroy/flagdayparade.html |accessdate=2009-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415210324/http://www.troyny.gov/visittroy/flagdayparade.html |archivedate=2009-04-15 |df= }}</ref> [[First Night]] celebrations are held in Saratoga Springs, while in 2006 Albany decided to eliminate its First Night celebrations in favor of a new "Albany WinterFestival" (WinterFest).<ref>{{cite web | title = New event to premier as Albany's First Night fades away | publisher = Albany Business Review | url = http://albany.bizjournals.com/albany/stories/2006/12/25/daily33.html | date = December 29, 2006 | accessdate = 2009-06-08}}</ref>
Other major festivals in the Capital District include ethnic festivals. The Albany LatinFest which has been held since 1996 and drew 10,000 to Washington Park in 2008.<ref>{{cite web | title = About Albany Latin Fest | url = http://www.albanylatinfest.com/about.html | publisher = Albany Latin Festival | accessdate = 2009-06-08 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090616140515/http://www.albanylatinfest.com/about.html# | archive-date = 2009-06-16 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> In Schenectady the growing [[Demographics of Guyana|Guyanese]] community has celebrated the Guyanese Family Fun Day for several years in that city's Central Park.<ref>{{cite web|title=Schenectady Festival Celebrates the Culture and Community of Immigrants from Guyana |date=September 2, 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-26 |url=http://spotlightnews.com/spotlightfeature/article.php?article_id=tE1251921792t4a9ecf802f26b |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716122411/http://spotlightnews.com/spotlightfeature/article.php?article_id=tE1251921792t4a9ecf802f26b |archivedate=2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> PolishFest is a three-day celebration of Polish culture in the Capital District, held in the town of Colonie for the past eight years.<ref>{{cite web | title = PolishFest'09 | url = http://www.polishfest-ny.org/}}</ref>
==Literature and cinema== [[File:EmmaWillardSchool.JPG|thumb|[[Emma Willard School]] was a film location for ''[[Scent of a Woman (1992 film)|Scent of a Woman]]'' and ''[[The Emperor's Club]]'']] The Capital District has its share of historical and tourist [[non-fiction]] books; the area however has also seen a great deal of [[fiction]] written by its natives and about the region. Some of these have been turned into movies, such as ''[[Ironweed (novel)|Ironweed]]'' by [[William Kennedy (author)|William Kennedy]] and ''[[Last of the Mohicans]]'' by [[James Fenimore Cooper]]. ''Ironweed'' is but one of a series of books by Kennedy that take place in Albany. The series is often referred to as the "Albany Cycle". The elusive author [[Trevanian]] also grew up in Albany and wrote ''The Crazyladies of Pearl Street'', about Albany's [[Neighborhoods of Albany, New York#North Albany|North Albany]] neighborhood along [[Streets of Albany, New York#Pearl Street|Pearl Street]]; commentators considered it a semi-autobiographical memoir.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trevanian Books/The Crazyladies of Pearl Street |publisher=Gravity Publishing |accessdate=2010-07-25 |url=http://www.trevanian.com/books/crazyladies.htm}}</ref> [[Gregory Maguire]], author of [[Wicked: The Life and Times of the Wicked Witch of the West]] which was source for the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] hit [[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]], also grew up in North Albany.<ref>{{cite web | title = Albany book festival showcases power of storytelling | author = Steve Barnes | publisher = Albany Times Union | date = April 11, 2010 | accessdate = 2010-04-11 | url = http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=920526}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> [[Richard Lipez]], under the pen-name Richard Stevenson has written nine books (four of which have been made into movies) in a series about the openly [[gay]] detective [[Donald Strachey]], which take place in Albany.
From the earliest days of silent movies the Capital District has been used for filming motion pictures.<ref name=Moremovies/> Some early movies filmed in the area were ''[[Last of the Mohicans]]'' in 1911, ''The Sign Invisible'' (1918), and ''Impossible Catherine'' (1919), all of which were filmed in [[Lake George (village), New York|Lake George]]. ''[[Saratoga (film)|Saratoga]]'', produced in 1937, was shot at the [[Saratoga Race Course]].<ref name=Moremovies/> In the 1990s, after several movies were filmed in the area, the marketing moniker "Hollywood on the Hudson" was promoted for the area, but never gained popularity,<ref name=Moremovies/> though it still is used by some promoters, especially for Troy.<ref name=Troymovies/>
More recently there have been many movies that have had parts filmed in the Capital District including ''[[The Bostonians (film)|The Bostonians]]'' (1984),<ref name=Troymovies>{{cite web | title = History of Troy- Cultural footnotes... | publisher = Uncle Sam's Place | accessdate = 2009-11-22 | url = http://www.uncle-sams-home.com/troyhis7.html}}</ref> ''[[Ironweed (film)|Ironweed]]'' (1987),<ref name=Troymovies/> ''[[Scent of a Woman (1992 film)|Scent of a Woman]]'' (1992),<ref name=Troymovies/> ''[[The Age of Innocence (1993 film)|The Age of Innocence]]'' (1993),<ref name=Troymovies/> ''[[The Horse Whisperer (film)|The Horse Whisperer]]'' (1998),<ref name=Moremovies>{{cite web | title = Co-starring the Capital Region | publisher = Albany Times Union | author = Mark McGuire | accessdate = 2009-11-22 | date = September 24, 2006 | url = http://archives.timesunion.com/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=6420112 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ''[[The Emperor's Club]]'' (2002),<ref name=Moremovies/> ''[[The Time Machine (2002 film)|The Time Machine]]'' (2002),<ref name=Moremovies/> ''[[Seabiscuit (film)|Seabiscuit]]'' (2003),<ref name=Moremovies/> ''[[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|War of the Worlds]]'' (2005),<ref name=Moremovies/> and ''[[Taking Woodstock]]'' (2009).<ref name=Jolie/> Most recently [[Downtown Albany Historic District|Downtown Albany]] was the site of filming for ''[[Salt (2010 film)|Salt]]'' starring [[Angelina Jolie]],<ref name=Jolie>{{cite web|title=Jolie movie to shut down Albany roads |author=Danielle Furfaro |publisher=Albany Times Union |accessdate=2009-04-22 |date=April 21, 2009 |url=http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=792014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422222955/http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=792014 |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }}</ref> and the action-comedy ''[[The Other Guys]]'' starring [[Will Ferrell]] and [[Mark Wahlberg]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Bright lights, our city | publisher = Albany Times Union | accessdate = 2009-11-22 | date = October 8, 2009 | url = http://archives.timesunion.com/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=8820193 | author = Chris Churchill }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Religious life== [[File:First Reformed Church, Albany.jpg|thumb|left|[[First Church in Albany (Reformed)|First Church in Albany]], a Reformed church, the oldest place of worship in the Capital District]] The Capital District, and Albany in particular, is home to many of the oldest congregations and places of worship in the United States. The Dutch Reformed, Episcopal, and Lutheran congregations date back to the 17th century. The area, as a Dutch colony originally, was dominated by the Dutch Reformed church from the beginning of settlement. The congregation of the [[First Church in Albany]] is the second oldest congregation in the state of New York.<ref name=Church>{{cite web | title = First Church in Albany: Our History | url = http://www.firstchurchinalbany.org/ | publisher = First Church in Albany | accessdate = 2009-04-14}}</ref> The [[pulpit]] was imported from the Netherlands in 1656 and is the oldest pulpit in the United States.<ref name=Church/> Shortly after being constructed a memorial service was held for [[Alexander Hamilton]] here, and [[Theodore Roosevelt]] attended services here while [[Governor (New York)|Governor of New York]]. The [[First Lutheran Church (Albany, New York)|First Lutheran Church]] in Albany is the oldest congregation of the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]], it began as a [[Dutch Lutheran Church|Dutch Lutheran]] church 360 years ago.<ref>{{cite web | title = Site housed Albany's oldest Lutheran church | publisher = Albany Times Union | author = Peter R. Christoph | accessdate = 2009-11-27 | date = June 12, 1998 | url = http://archives.timesunion.com/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=5928323 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[St. Peter's Episcopal Church (Albany, New York)|St. Peter's]] was the first [[Anglican]] church in New York west of the Hudson River,<ref>{{cite book | author = Cuyler Reynolds | title = Albany Chronicles | accessdate = 2009-01-18 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=XNU0AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA17&dq=castle+island+french+fort+1540&lr=#PPR4,M1 | pages = 185–187 | year = 1906}}</ref> and the first Anglican church in the state north of the city of New York. The remains of Lord Howe, who died during the [[French and Indian Wars]] were [[interred]] under the [[vestibule (architecture)|vestibule]];<ref>{{cite book | author = Cuyler Reynolds | title = Albany Chronicles | accessdate = 2009-01-18 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=XNU0AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA17&dq=castle+island+french+fort+1540&lr=#PPR4,M1 | page = 641 | year = 1906}}</ref> he is the only British Lord buried in the United States.<ref name=Facts>{{cite web | title = Albany Fun Facts | accessdate = 2009-01-22 | publisher = Albany County Convention and Visitor's Bureau | url = http://www.albany.org/aboutalbany/FunFacts.aspx}}</ref><ref name=Rittner>{{cite book | title = Images of America: Albany | ISBN = 0-7385-0088-7 | author = Don Rittner | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | year = 2000}}</ref> In 1868 the newly formed [[Episcopal Diocese of Albany]] met in convention at St. Peter's to choose a bishop and [[William Doane]], rector of St. Peter's, was chosen on December 3, he was consecrated as such on February 2, 1869 in St. Peter's.<ref>{{cite book | author = Cuyler Reynolds | title = Albany Chronicles | accessdate = 2009-01-18 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=XNU0AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA17&dq=castle+island+french+fort+1540&lr=#PPR4,M1 | page = 658 | year = 1906}}</ref> Albany remains the home of the [[mother church]] and [[cathedral]] of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]]<ref>{{cite web |title=The Diocese of Albany: A Brief History of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany |publisher=Episcopal Diocese of Albany |url=http://www.albanyepiscopaldiocese.org/about/history.html |accessdate=25 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422074058/http://www.albanyepiscopaldiocese.org/about/history.html# |archive-date=2006-04-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[diocese]] of Albany: the [[Cathedral of All Saints (Albany, New York)|Cathedral of All Saints]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Cathedral of All Saints |publisher=Episcopal Diocese of Albany |url=http://www.albanyepiscopaldiocese.org/churches/albany.html#Albany |accessdate=25 May 2009}}</ref> with [[List of Episcopal bishops (U.S.)|Bishop]] [[William Love (bishop)|William Love]] as current bishop.<ref>{{cite web |title=Episcopal Diocese of Albany: Clergy Directory - Bishops |publisher=Episcopal Diocese of Albany |url=http://www.albanyepiscopaldiocese.org/directories/bishops.html |accessdate=25 May 2009}}</ref>
The Capital District is also home to the [[Roman Catholicism in the United States|Roman Catholic]] cathedral and mother church,<ref name=RCDioceseHist>{{cite web |title=Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany: A Brief History |publisher=Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany |url=http://www.rcda.org/history.html |accessdate=25 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430200024/http://www.rcda.org/history.html# |archive-date=2009-04-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> the [[Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Albany, New York)|Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception]]<ref name = RCDioceseHist/> with [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|Bishop]] [[Howard James Hubbard|Howard J. Hubbard]] as head of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany: Bishop's Welcome Message |publisher=Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany |url=http://www.rcda.org/our_bishop.html |accessdate=25 May 2009}}</ref>
The oldest [[Black church]] in the Capital District is the Israel [[African Methodist Episcopal Church]] (Israel AME), it was established by Reverend William Cornish who was sent to Albany in 1828 by [[Bishop]] [[Richard Allen (bishop)|Richard Allen]], founder of the AME [[denomination (Christianity)|denomination]]. The Israel AME was incorporated in 1829 and the current building on Hamilton Street dates from 1854. A state historic marker was placed in 1988 at the 160th anniversary celebrations, which also commemorates the church as a stop on the [[Underground Railroad]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Capital District's oldest Black church celebrates heritage 160-year-old Israel AME Church lays cornerstone today | accessdate = 2009-11-20 | publisher = Albany Times Union | author = Grace O'Connor | date = May 7, 1988}}</ref>
A significant [[Jew]]ish presence has existed in Albany since as early as 1658,<ref name=Judaica/> and today includes many [[synagogue]]s; there are two [[Reform Judaism|Reform]], two [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]], a [[Chabad-Lubavitch]], an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]], and one of the few [[Karaite Judaism|Karaite]] synagogues outside [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Synagogues in Albany |publisher=MavenSearch (Jewish Web Directory) |url=http://www.mavensearch.com/synagogues/C3329Y3783RX |accessdate=2010-06-22 |year=2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Homepage |publisher=Karaite Jewish Congregation Oraḥ Ṣaddiqim |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-06-22 |url=http://www.orahsaddiqim.org/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414060746/http://www.orahsaddiqim.org/ |archivedate=April 14, 2009 }} ''This link is not active during [[Shabbat]], which begins on Friday at sundown, [[Eastern Time Zone|local time]], and ends the following Saturday night.''</ref> [[Congregation Berith Sholom]] (Covenant of Peace), a synagogue in Troy, is the oldest continuously used synagogue in the state of New York, and the second oldest house of worship in the state outside of the [[New York City|city of New York]],.<ref name=Expansion>{{cite web |title=Congregation Berith Sholom Anniversary Expansion Capital Project |url=http://www.berithsholom.org/_kd/Items/actions.cfm?action=Show&item_id=1128&destination=ShowItem |publisher=Congregation Berith Sholom |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724023021/http://www.berithsholom.org/_kd/Items/actions.cfm?action=Show&item_id=1128&destination=ShowItem |archivedate=2009-07-24 |df= }}</ref>
In addition, Albany is known for a landmark event in the history of American Reform Judaism: [[Rabbi]] [[Isaac Mayer Wise]], one of the founders of [[Reform Judaism]] in the United States, first advocated his reforms at a synagogue in Albany, where he was Albany's first and only rabbi.<ref name=Judaica/><ref>{{cite web |title=Isaac Mayer Wise: Architect of American Reform Judaism |first=Samuel M |last=Stahl |publisher=Temple Beth-El (San Antonio, Texas) |url=http://www.beth-elsa.org/be_s0324.htm |accessdate=2010-06-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531035826/http://www.beth-elsa.org/be_s0324.htm# |archive-date=2009-05-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Wise was also the teacher of one of only four Hebrew schools in the nation.<ref name=Judaica/> In 1850 he came to blows with the congregation president and the police were called to quell the riot that started on the street.<ref>{{cite web | title = Isaac Mayer Wise: Architect of American Reform Judaism | author = Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl | publisher = Temple Beth-El (San Antonio, Texas) | url = http://www.beth-elsa.org/be_s0324.htm | access-date = 2009-11-20 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090531035826/http://www.beth-elsa.org/be_s0324.htm# | archive-date = 2009-05-31 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> and this split with the existing synagogue he established in Albany the fourth Reform synagogue in the United States.<ref name=Judaica>{{cite web | title = Albany (re-published from Encyclopedia Judaica) | url = http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0001_0_00672.html | publisher = The American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise | accessdate = 2010-06-26}}</ref>
There is also a small population of [[Muslim]]s in the city. The number of colleges and universities in the area help bring in more culturally diverse students, representing ranging religious beliefs. Most of the local colleges have respective Muslim Student Associations, for example.<ref>{{cite web |title=Local Muslim Student Associations |publisher=Albany-Area Muslims Website |url=http://www.jannah.org/albany/msas.html |year= |accessdate=2010-06-22}}</ref> SUNY Albany even cancelled class for [[Eid al-Fitr]] and [[Eid al-Adha]] during the 2004–2005 school year, however it reverted that policy the following year due to low Muslim population.<ref>{{cite news |title=A Muslim Holiday and Classes Go On |last=Yusko |first=Dennis |publisher=Hearst Newspapers |work=Times Union (Albany) |page=A1 |date=2009-09-18 |accessdate=2010-06-22 |url=http://albarchive.merlinone.net/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=8701663}}</ref>

In developmental [[biology]] and [[zoology]], '''defeminization''' is an aspect of the process of [[sexual differentiation]] by which a potential female-specific structure, function, or behavior is changed by one of the processes of male development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/defeminization|title=Defeminization definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref> Although the term might seem to imply "removal" of female characteristics, in nearly all biological contexts it refers to ''prevention'' of an aspect of female development from manifesting.
In human [[biology of gender]], the best known example of this is the prevention of development of the [[müllerian duct]] derivatives by [[anti-müllerian hormone]] (AMH) in the 3rd and 4th months of [[fetus|fetal]] development, though the term is not commonly used in discussions of human development.
In a number of non-human [[mammal]]s, there is evidence that hormones produced by the testes act directly on the [[brain]] to prevent development of female characteristics, especially female [[Animal sexual behavior|reproductive behavior]].

'''Elkpen''' (aka '''Christian Kasperkovitz''') is a street artist based in Los Angeles, California whose work contemplates the effect of urban life on familiar, threatened or extinct flora and fauna. Elkpen can do her work in any size, place or thing that offers itself, sometimes it's a retail or corporate setting. Sometimes even a park bench, matchbook or post card her work may appear on. Her work has reached numerous cities and counties such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York, Canada and Mexico.<ref name="KCET street art">{{cite web|last1=Fuentes|first1=Ed|title=Street Art Writes New Rules on Urban Linguistics|url=http://www.kcet.org/socal/departures/columns/writing-on-the-wall/street-art-writes-new-rules-on-urban-linguistics.html|website=www.kcet.org|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> In 2014, she was commissioned to create the design on the exterior of the Los Angeles River Rover, a mobile classroom which is used to teach students about the significance of the [[Los Angeles River]] to wildlife in the city. Elkpen also takes the time to do work shops with youth, presentations for communities and non profit organizations. She also associates with corporate clients to create authentic and socially progressive images and content.<ref name="KCET River Rover">{{cite web|last1=Jao|first1=Carren|title=River Rover Rolls into L.A. River Day|url=http://www.kcet.org/socal/departures/lariver/confluence/river-notes/river-rover-rolls-into-la-river-day.html|website=www.kcet.org|publisher=KCET|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="LA RIVER ROVER GLENDALE">{{cite web|last1=Sahagun|first1=Louis|title=L.A. River Rover teaches students to appreciate an urban habitat|url=http://www.glendalenewspress.com|website=www.glendalenewspress.com|publisher=Glendale News Press|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sahagun|first1=Louis|title=Mobile classroom rolls out to teach students about L.A. River|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/apr/13/local/la-me-river-rover-20140414|accessdate=9 March 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=April 13, 2014}}</ref>
Elkpen's work has been seen on buildings, busses, beaches, fences, light poles and bus benches in the US and Canada. She has been working as a freelance artist for over 20 years with the slogan in the back of her mind "no job is too large or too small".<ref name="buzz w artist photo">{{cite web|last1=Grist|first1=Julie|title=Elusive Environmental Artist "Elkpen" in Larchmont|url=http://www.larchmontbuzz.com/larchmont-village-people/elusive-environmental-artist-elkpen-in-larchmont/|website=www.larchmontbuzz.com|publisher=Larchmont Buzz - Larchmont Village Newspaper|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
Elkpen's work uses both images and words to convey biological, historical, and environmental information to draw the viewer's attention to the wildlife or lack of wildlife in a particular location. The key that distinguishes her projects from other people is her ability to hand draw images with great quality. Hand drawn images are more natural plus can give off a more lively feel for the viewers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grist|first1=Julie|title=Elusive Environmental Artist "Elkpen" in Larchmont|url=http://www.larchmontbuzz.com/larchmont-village-people/elusive-environmental-artist-elkpen-in-larchmont/|website=www.larchmontbuzz.com|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
Elkpen's subjects have included cottonwood trees, alder trees, coastal prairies, Grizzlies, Giant Swallowtail and Anise Swallowtail butterflies, Fairy Shrimp, Western Kingbirds, Goldfinches, Northern Mockingbirds, Yellow Chevroned Parakeets, Black Phoebes, Woodpeckers, Crows, Bushtits and many other birds found in Southern California. She also works with clients to create authentic and socially progressive images and content that weave together a connection to place and the community around it as well as the clients overall mission.<ref name="LA WEEKLY bird mural">{{cite web|last1=Mauer such creatures as|first1=Mark|title=BIRDS OF HOLLYWOOD, ELKPEN, FOUNTAIN AVE MARKET|url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/birds-of-hollywood-elkpen-fountain-ave-market-2368054|website=www.laweekly.com|publisher=LA Weekly|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>

{{about|the 4th century alphabet of the Gothic Bible|manuscript hands and typefaces sometimes referred to as "Gothic script"|Blackletter|type fonts sometimes referred to as "Gothic"|Sans-serif}} {{Infobox Writing system |name=Gothic |languages=[[Gothic language|Gothic]] |type=[[Alphabet]] |time=From c. 350, in decline by 600 |fam1=Mostly [[Greek alphabet|Greek]], with [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] and [[Runic alphabet|Runic]] influences (questionable) |unicode=[https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U10330.pdf U+10330–U+1034F] |iso15924=Goth |sample=Wulfila bibel.jpg |imagesize=200px }} {{Contains Gothic text}} {{alphabet}} The '''Gothic alphabet''' is an [[alphabet]] for writing the [[Gothic language]], created in the 4th century by [[Ulfilas]] (or Wulfila) for the purpose of [[Bible translations|translating the Bible]].According to the testimony of the historians [[Philostorgius]], [[Socrates of Constantinople]] and [[Sozomen]]. Cf. Streitberg (1910:20). The alphabet is essentially an [[uncial script|uncial]] form of the [[Greek alphabet]], with a few additional letters to account for Gothic phonology: [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[F]] and [[G]], a questionably [[Runic alphabet|Runic]] letter to distinguish the /w/ [[Semivowel|glide]] from vocalic /u/, and the letter [[ƕair]] to express the Gothic [[Labialized velar consonant|labiovelar]]. ==Origin== Ulfilas is thought to have consciously chosen to avoid the use of the older [[Runic alphabet]] for this purpose, as it was heavily connected with [[Germanic paganism|heathen]] beliefs and customs.Cf. Jensen (1969:474). Also, the Greek-based script probably helped to integrate the Gothic nation into the dominant [[Greco-Roman world|Greco-Roman]] culture around the [[Black Sea]].Cf. Haarmann (1991:434). ==Letters== Below is a table of the Gothic alphabet.For a discussion of the Gothic alphabet see also [[Fausto Cercignani]], ''The Elaboration of the Gothic Alphabet and Orthography'', in “Indogermanische Forschungen”, 93, 1988, pp. 168-185. Two letters used in its [[transliteration]] are not used in current English: thorn ''[[Thorn (letter)|þ]]'' (representing {{IPAslink|θ}}), and hwair ''[[Hwair|ƕ]]'' (representing {{IPAslink|ʍ|hʷ}}). As with the Greek alphabet, Gothic letters were also assigned numerical values. When used as numerals, letters were written either between two dots (•{{lang|got|𐌹𐌱}}• = 12) or with an overline ({{lang|got|𐌹𐌱}} = 12). Two letters, {{lang|got|𐍁}} (90) and {{lang|got|𐍊}} (900), have no phonetic value. The letter names are recorded in a 9th-century manuscript of [[Alcuin]] ([[Codex Vindobonensis 795]]). Most of them seem to be Gothic forms of names also appearing in the [[rune poem]]s. The names are given in their attested forms followed by the reconstructed Gothic forms and their meanings.The forms which are not attested in the Gothic corpus are marked with an asterisk. For a detailed discussion of the reconstructed forms, cf. Kirchhoff (1854). For a survey of the relevant literature, cf. Zacher (1855).

Most of the letters have been taken over directly from the [[Greek alphabet]], though a few have been created or modified from Latin and possibly (more controversially) Runic letters to express unique phonological features of Gothic. These are: * {{lang|got|𐌵}} (q; derived either from a form of Greek [[Stigma (letter)|stigma]]/[[digamma]] ([[File:Greek Digamma cursive 06.svg|x16px]]),Magnús Snædal ('''2015'''). “Gothic Contact with Latin” in ''Early Germanic Languages in Contact'', Ed. John Ole Askedal and Hans Frede Nielsen. or from a cursive variant of [[kappa| kappa (ϰ)]], which could strongly resemble a ''[[u]]'', or by inverting Greek [[Pi (letter)|pi (𐍀)]] /p/, perhaps due to similarity in the Gothic names: ''pairþa'' versus ''qairþa''{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}}) * {{lang|got|𐌸}} (þ; derived either from Greek [[phi (letter)|phi (Φ)]] /f/ or [[psi (letter)|psi (Ψ)]] /ps/ with phonetic reassignment; possibly the letterform was switched with {{lang|got|𐍈}}) * {{lang|got|𐌾}} (j; derived from Latin [[G]] /ɡ/) * {{lang|got|𐌿}} (u; possibly an allograph of Greek [[Ο]] (cf. the numerical values), or (less plausibly) from Runic {{script|Runr|[[ᚢ]]}} /u/)Cf. Kirchhoff (1854:55). * {{lang|got|𐍈}} (ƕ; derived from Greek [[Theta|Θ]] /θ/ with phonetic reassignment; possibly the letterform was switched with {{lang|got|𐌸}}) * {{lang|got|𐍉}} (o; derived either from Greek [[Ω]] or from Runic {{script|Runr|[[ᛟ]]}},Haarmann (1991:434). or from a cursive form of Greek [[Ο]], as such a form was more common for omicron than for omega in this time period, and as the sound values of omicron and omega had already merged by this time) {{lang|got|𐍂}} (r), {{lang|got|𐍃}} (s) and {{lang|got|𐍆}} (f) appear to be derived from their Latin equivalents rather than from the Greek, although the equivalent Runic letters ({{script|Runr|[[Raido|ᚱ]]}}, {{script|Runr|[[Sowilo rune|ᛋ]]}} and {{script|Runr|[[Fehu|ᚠ]]}}), assumed to have been part of the Gothic futhark, possibly played some role in this choice.Cf. Kirchhoff (1854:55-56); Friesen (1915:306-310). However, Snædal notes that “Wulfila’s knowledge of runes was questionable to say the least”, as the extreme paucity of inscriptions attests that knowledge and use of runes was rare among the East Germanic peoples. No indisputably Gothic Runic inscriptions are known to exist. Some variants of {{lang|got|𐍃}} (s) are shaped like a sigma and more obviously derive from the Greek [[Σ]]. {{lang|got|𐍇}} (x) is only used in proper names and loanwords containing Greek [[chi (letter)|Χ]] (''xristus'' "Christ", ''galiugaxristus'' "Pseudo-Christ", ''zaxarias'' "Zacharias", ''aiwxaristia'' "eucharist").Wright (1910:5). Regarding the letters' numeric values, most correspond to those of the [[Greek numerals]]. Gothic {{lang|got|𐌵}} takes the place of [[digamma|Ϝ]] (6), {{lang|got|𐌾}} takes the place of [[xi (letter)|ξ]] (60), {{lang|got|𐌿}} that of [[omicron|Ο]] (70), and {{lang|got|𐍈}} that of [[psi (letter)|ψ]] (700). ==Diacritics and punctuation== Diacritics and punctuation used in the [[Codex Argenteus]] include a [[diaeresis (diacritic)|trema]] placed on {{lang|got|𐌹}} ''i'', transliterated as ''ï'', in general applied to express [[hiatus (linguistics)|diaeresis]], the [[interpunct]] (·) and [[Colon (punctuation)|colon]] (:) as well as [[overline]]s to indicate [[sigla]] (such as ''xaus'' for ''xristaus'') and numerals. [[File:Codex Argenteus.jpg|thumb|250px|First page of the ''[[Codex Argenteus]]'' or "Silver Bible", a 6th-century manuscript containing bishop [[Ulfilas]]'s 4th century translation of the Christian [[Bible]] into the [[Gothic language]].]] ==Unicode== The Gothic alphabet was added to the [[Unicode]] Standard in March, 2001 with the release of version 3.1. The Unicode block for Gothic is U+10330–U+1034F in the ''Supplementary Multilingual Plane''. As older software that uses [[UCS-2]] (the predecessor of [[UTF-16]]) assumes that all Unicode codepoints can be expressed as 16 [[bit]] numbers (U+FFFF or lower, the ''Basic Multilingual Plane''), problems may be encountered using the Gothic alphabet Unicode range and others outside of the ''Basic Multilingual Plane''. {{Unicode chart Gothic}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==See also== * [[Ring of Pietroassa]] * [[Help:Gothic Unicode Fonts]] ==References== * [[Wilhelm Braune|Braune, Wilhelm]] (1952). [[Image:Grave orb.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A grave orb in the [[Swedish Museum of National Antiquities]] in [[Stockholm]]]] [[Image:Carved stones (150424524).jpg|thumb|right|Inglinge Hög burial mound]] '''Grave Orb''' is the name for a [[petrosphere]] that was put on the tomb of a deceased. Grave Orbs were made throughout [[Scandinavia]] from the [[Pre-Roman Iron Age]] until the [[Vendel era]].
The Grave Orb could have been selected for its round shape or shaped by hand. They were then put in the centre of a burial site. [[tumulus|Tumuli]], [[Stone circle (Iron Age)|stone circle]]s and [[stone ship]]s often have a reclined or raised central stone, and grave orbs derive from this practice. They were of ritual or symbolic significance.
Some grave orbs are engraved with ornaments, such as the orb at ''Inglinge hög'' or Barrow of Inglinge near [[Ingelstad]] in [[Småland]]. ''Hög'' is from the [[Old Norse]] word ''haugr'' meaning mound or barrow.

{{refimprove|date=November 2013}} [[Image:Scroll.jpg|200px|thumb|Scroll of the [[Book of Esther]], [[Seville]], [[Spain]]]] A '''[[scroll]]''' (from the Old French ''escroe'' or ''escroue''), is a roll of [[papyrus]], [[parchment]], or [[paper]] containing writing.Beal, Peter. (2008) "scroll" in ''A Dictionary of English Manuscript Terminology 1450–2000'' Online edition. [[Oxford University Press]], 2008. http://www.oxfordreference.com Retrieved 21 November 2013. The '''history of scrolls''' dates back to ancient Egypt. In most ancient literate cultures scrolls were the earliest format for longer documents written in ink or paint on a flexible background, preceding bound [[book]]s; rigid media such as [[clay tablet]]s were also used but had many disadvantages in comparison. For most purposes scrolls have long been superseded by the [[codex]] book format, but they are still produced for some ceremonial or religious purposes, notably for the Jewish [[Torah scroll]] for use in [[synagogue]]s. ==Origins in Africa== Scrolls were the first form of editable record keeping texts, used in Eastern Mediterranean [[ancient Egyptian civilization]]s. Parchment scrolls were used by several early civilizations before the [[codex]] or bound [[book]] with pages and was invented by the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] in the 1st century AD{{fact|date=April 2018}}. Nevertheless, scrolls were more highly regarded than codices until well into Roman times where they were usually written in single latitudinal column. ==Eastern Mediterranean, West Asia and Europe== ===Israel=== The Hebrew tradition assumes that the [[Torah]] was copied by [[Moses]] onto a scroll (in about 1200 BCE) made from skin of a [[kosher]] animal, rather than [[papyrus]] as in Dynastic Egypt. Since there is no historical evidence for Moses and the events related in the Torah, there is no reliable way to know the time when Hebrews started using scrolls for their religious books.{{cite book | author=Dever, William G. | title=What Did the Biblical Writers Know and When Did They Know It? | publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company | year=2002 | isbn=978-0-8028-2126-3}}p. 99 Following Jewish tradition, since that time scrolls, which are very durable with examples known to be hundreds of years old such as the 800-year-old Sephardic [[Sefer Torah]] from Spain, are copied from one to another. The meticulous process of hand-copying a scroll takes about 2,000 person-hours (about one year at 40 hours per week). The Torah scroll contains 304,805 letters (or approximately 79,000 words).
Other books of the [[Tanakh]] are also written in scroll form, as well as the small [[mezuzah]] scrolls found in the door frames of most orthodox, conservative and reform Jewish households. Some Jewish families own their own [[Megillah (Talmud)|Megillah]] scroll for use during [[Purim]]. There is a difference between the [[Qere and Ketiv|כְּתִיב (''Ketiv'')]], what is and must be written (in consonantal text, with vowels omitted), and the קְרֵי (''Qere''), what is read. ===Syria and Babylon=== The Jewish communities in these countries used the same techniques to manufacture scrolls, but using deer skins. The scrolls from these areas were known for their quality and durability, and were later imported into European and Indian communities. Non-Jewish vellum manufacturing also took place after the 3rd century BC. ===Greece and Rome=== {{double image|right|Giovane con rotolo.JPG|150|MANNapoli 120620 a Fresco young man with rolls from Pompeii Italy.jpg|150|[[Roman portraiture]] [[fresco]]s from [[Pompeii]], 1st century AD, depicting two different men wearing [[laurel wreath]]s, one holding the ''[[rotulus]]'', the other a ''volumen''}} [[File:Busto maschile.JPG|thumb|[[Roman portraiture]] fresco of a young man with a [[papyrus]] [[scroll]], from [[Herculaneum]], 1st century AD]] Scrolls were used by the ancient Greeks. In Roman usage the scrolls were written latitudinally, usually placed on podiums with roll holders from which the rolls were unwound.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The Romans eventually found the scroll too cumbersome for lengthy works and developed the [[codex]], which is the formal name for the modern style of book, with individual pages bound together. ===Early Christian era=== Scrolls continued to be used at times during the Early Church era until the [[Early Middle Ages]], but Christianity was an early adopter of the codex. It is often thought that this reflects the background in trade of many early Christians, who were used to codex notebooks, and less attached to the form that was traditional among the Roman elite and religious Jews. ===European Middle Ages=== Scrolls virtually ceased to be used for books and documents in Europe during the [[Middle Ages]], and were reintroduced for rare use in official treaties and other international documents of great significance during and after the Baroque Era of the 0th century. These were usually written on high quality vellum, and stored in elaborate silver and gold cases inscribed with names of participants. Earlier examples were written in Latin. Scrolls continued in use for administrative and accounting purposes all over Europe. In English they were often referred to as "rolls", hence the [[Pipe rolls|Great Rolls]] of the English [[Exchequer]], and titles such as [[Master of the Rolls]] (a senior judge), still used in the 21st century. The official copy of English, now British, legislation was still printed on vellum in a roll format and stored in the [[Palace of Westminster]] until 2017, when the use of Vellum was replaced with archival paperhttps://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/21/anger-mps-bow-peers-pressure-end-500-year-old-tradition-printing/. The [[Exultet Scroll]] from Southern Italy and Byzantine [[Joshua Scroll]] were prestige objects that used the old form in a revivalist spirit. ===West and Central Asia=== Scrolls continued in use longer in the Islamic world, often elaborately decorated in calligraphic writing that included use of gold embossing and pigments when used for the writing of the Qur'an. ===East Asia=== {{see also|Hanging scroll|Handscroll}} Scrolls continued in use longer in East Asian cultures like China, Korea and Japan. The Chinese invented and perfected 'Indian Ink' for use in writing, including scrolls. Originally designed for blacking the surfaces of raised stone-carved hieroglyphics, the ink was a mixture of soot from pine smoke and lamp oil mixed with the gelatin of donkey skin and musk. The ink invented by the Chinese philosopher, Tien-Lcheu (2697 B.C.){{fact|date=April 2018}}, became common by the year 1200 B.C. Later other formats came into use in China, firstly the ''sutra'' or ''scripture'' binding, a scroll folded [[concertina]]-style, which avoids the need to unroll to find a passage in the middle. By about 1,000 CE, sheet-based formats were introduced, although scrolls continued to have a place. Traditional [[painting]] and [[calligraphy]] in East Asia is often still performed on relatively short latitudinal paper scrolls displayed vertically as a [[hanging scroll]] on a wall or horizontally and flat as a [[handscroll]]. {{wide image|Gu Kaizhi. Wise and Benevolent Women. Scroll. Song copy of 4 century work. Palace museum, Beizing.jpg|4800px|Song Dynasty copy of the ''Wise and Benevolent Women'', original by [[Gu Kaizhi]], 13th century, [[Palace Museum]].}} ==Replacement by the ''Codex''== The [[codex]] was a new format for reading the written word, consisting of individual pages loosely attached to each other at one side and bound with boards or cloth. It came to replace the scroll thanks to several problems that limited the scroll's function and readability. For one, scrolls were very long, sometimes as long as ten meters. This made them hard to hold open and read, a difficulty not helped by the fact that most scrolls in that era were read horizontally, instead of vertically as scrolling virtual documents are read now. The text on a scroll was continuous, without page breaks, which made indexing and bookmarking impossible. Conversely, the codex was easier to hold open, separate pages made it possible to index sections and mark a page, and the protective covers kept the fragile pages intact better than scrolls generally stayed. This last made it particularly attractive for important religious texts.Lyons, M. (2011) ''Books: A Living History.'' Los Angeles, CA: Getty Publications. p. 35-36 Another aspect that made the codex more attractive than the scroll was ease of copying. It was possible to hold open a codex with one hand and write notes- or copy the text- with the other. For early Christendom this was an invaluable asset, as the ability to mass reproduce their gospels was in high demand. Early Medieval Christians were some of the first to adopt the codex over the scroll.Frost, Gary, [http://cool.conservation-us.org/coolaic/sg/bpg/annual/v17/bp17-10.html "Adoption of the Codex Book: Parable of a New Reading Mode"], ''The Book and Paper Group Annual'', Retrieved 12/1/2014 The codex began to replace the scroll almost as soon as it was invented. For example, in Egypt by the fifth century, the codex outnumbered the scroll or roll by ten to one based on surviving examples, and by the sixth century the scroll had almost vanished from use as a vehicle for literature.Roberts, Colin H., and Skeat, T.C. (1987), ''The Birth of the Codex''. London: [[Oxford University Press]] for the [[British Academy]], p. 75. However, in other places the scroll lingered. As mentioned above, English monarchs used so called “statute rolls” to record important legislation until well into the Middle Ages. Scrolls were also commonly used in theater productions, a practice from which the term “actor’s roll” was coined.Lyons, M. (2011) ''Books: A Living History.'' Los Angeles, CA: Getty Publications. p. 37 ==Modern era== [[File:Hanging scroll 7a33a8.jpg|thumb|[[Hanging scroll]]s of [[Chinese calligraphy|calligraphy]] on display, [[Shanghai]]]] Torah Scrolls are still used today in Jewish religious observance with almost insignificant changes despite the thousands of years in practice. Some cultures use scrolls as ceremonial texts or for decoration—such as a [[hanging scroll]]—without any obvious division of the text into columns. In some scroll-using cultures painted illustrations were used as header decorations above the text columns, either in a continuous band or broken into scenes above either a single or double column of text. One of the few modern texts the original of which was written on what is effectively a scroll is the manuscript of [[Jack Kerouac]]'s ''[[On the Road]]'', typed onto what he called "the scroll", made of taped-together sheets of paper. The verb "[[Scrolling|to scroll]]" is much used in the age of [[Display device|screen]] displays—[[computer]] displays, rolling [[Closing credits|credits]] in [[film]]s and so on—with the screen filled with text moving (scrolling) up or down or sideways, appearing at one edge of the display and disappearing at the other as if being unrolled from one side of a scroll and rolled up at the other. == See also == * [[History of writing]] * [[History of books]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|scrolls}} *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/~grout/encyclopaedia_romana/scroll/scrollcodex.html Encyclopaedia Romana: "Scroll and codex"] [[Category:Manuscripts by type]] [[Category:History of books|Scrolls]]

[[File:S200.jpg|thumb|Isaak B. Klejman]] '''Isaac Bentsionovich Kleiman''' (11 January 1921 – February 13, 2012), is a Ukrainian Soviet archaeologist specialist in the history of antiquity.
== Biography == He studied at the Leningrad Artillery School (1939–1941). Member of the Great Patriotic War. After demobilization he graduated from the Faculty of History, [[University of Odessa]] (1952).
Field of interest - Antique Archaeology, especially in the western part of the Northern Black Sea coast, the ancient city of [[Tyras]] at the mouth of the [[Dniester]]. Published about 100 scientific papers.
From 1963 to 1988 - head and deputy head of the archaeological expedition to excavate ancient and medieval Tira Belgorod. Also participated in other archaeological expeditions in the [[North-West Black Sea region.]]
He worked at the Odessa Archaeological Museum, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, for several years headed the department of Classical Archaeology Museum.
== Books == The City of Tyras. A Historical and Archaeological Essay. Одесса: Polis-Press, 1994
== See also ==
* [http://www.archaeology.odessa.ua/ Одесский археологический музей], Украина г. Одесса ул. Ланжероновская, 4.

{{Italic title}} [[File:Katharsis November 2008.JPG|upright|thumb|''Katharsis'' November 2008]] '''''Katharsis''', A Critical Review in the Humanities and Social Sciences'', is a [[Hebrew]] [[periodical]] published twice a year and dedicated to detailed scholarly criticism of Hebrew publications in the [[Humanities]] and [[Social Studies]].
It is published and distributed by Carmel Publishing House, [[Jerusalem]]. ''Katharsis'' was established in 2004 by Mezaref, a non-profit-making society registered in Israel. The first editors were John Glucker, [[Doron Mendels]], and Moshe Shokeid.
Each issue opens – following the table of contents and editorial – by a 'programmatic' article criticizing some aspect of the manner in which study and research in the human disciplines are conducted in the Israeli academic world. Most of the main articles are 'review articles', dealing at length and in depth with books and articles in the Humanities and Social Studies published in Hebrew. The reviewers, experts in their respective fields, analyse in detail the book or article under review, citing exemplary passages for discussion, and deal with the methods (or lack of them) employed (or ignored) by the authors. The main aim of ''Katharsis'' is to raise academic standards by exposing errors, distortions and wilful deceptions in sub-standard publications; but some of the reviews praise works of serious scholarship and hold them up as examples to be followed.
Each issue ends with the section Remembrance of Former Generations, which includes a critical article or two by one of the leading Israeli scholars of the past century, preceded by a survey of his life and an assessment of his contributions to knowledge. Each issue also has a number of short, 1–2 page, 'pearls': quotations from books or articles pretending to present the reader with proper facts and explanations, while being full of basic errors. The editors explain what the errors are and what should have been written instead. At the back of each volume there is an [[English language|English]] title-page, and English summaries of the main articles.
The present [[editor in chief|editors]] are Yehuda Friedlander, John Glucker, [[Alon Harel]], Doron Mendels, and Amos Edelheit.
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.katharsis.co.il}} * [http://www.katharsis.co.il/forums.asp ''Katharsis'' section in English]

{{Location map+ |Georgia |width=400 |float=right|caption=Location of World Heritage Sites in Georgia. |places= {{location map~ |Georgia |lat=42.2972 |long=42.7611 |label=[[Gelati Monastery]]}} {{location map~ |Georgia |lat=41.85 |long=44.716667|label=[[Historical Monuments of Mtskheta]]}} {{location map~ |Georgia |lat=42.916389 |long=43.011389 |label=[[Upper Svaneti]]}} }} This is a '''list of World Heritage sites in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]''' as inscribed on the [[World Heritage site|World Heritage List]] of the [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO). The [[World Heritage site]]s are places of importance to [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage]] as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/ |title=The World Heritage Convention |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=21 September 2010}} Georgia accepted the convention on 4 November 1992, making its sites eligible for inclusion on the list. As of 2018, there are three World Heritage sites in Georgia, all of which are cultural sites.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ge/ |title=Georgia |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=6 August 2018}} In addition to its inscribed sites, Georgia also maintains fifteen properties on its tentative list. ==World Heritage sites== :'''Site'''; named after the World Heritage Committee's official designation{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} :'''Location'''; at city, regional, or provincial level and geocoordinates :'''Criteria'''; as defined by the World Heritage Committee{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} :'''Area'''; in [[hectare]]s and [[acre]]s. If available, the size of the buffer zone has been noted as well. A lack of value implies that no data has been published by UNESCO :'''Year'''; during which the site was inscribed to the World Heritage List :'''Description'''; brief information about the site, including reasons for qualifying as an endangered site, if applicable {|class="wikitable sortable" ! scope="col" | Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" | [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|Criteria]] ! scope="col"| Area
ha (acre) ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row" | [[Gelati Monastery]] | [[File:Gelati 1661.jpg|150px]] |[[Imereti]]
{{coord|42|15|44|N|42|42|59|E|region:GE_type:landmark|name=Bagrati Cathedral and Gelati Monastery}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{convert|7.87|ha|disp=b|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1994 |Gelati Monastery, a masterpiece of the [[Georgian Golden Age]], was built in 1106 by [[David IV of Georgia|King David IV]] and was one of the main cultural and intellectual centers in Georgia throughout the Middle Ages. It had an Academy which employed some of the most celebrated Georgian scientists, theologians and philosophers, many of whom had previously been active at various orthodox monasteries abroad, one of which was the [[Mangan Academy]] in [[Constantinople]]. In 2010–2017, the site, also including the [[Bagrati Cathedral]], was listed as [[List of World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] due to the cathedral undergoing major reconstruction detrimental to its integrity and authenticity. In 2017, Bagrati Cathedral was removed from the World Heritage list and Gelati Monastery delisted from the endangered list.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/1692|title=Gelati Monastery, Georgia, removed from UNESCO’s List of World Heritage in Danger|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre|date=|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=23 April 2018}}[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/710 Bagrati Cathedral and Gelati Monastery] [[UNESCO]]. Retrieved: June 5, 2013 |- ! scope="row" | [[Historical Monuments of Mtskheta]] | [[File:Gamsakhurdia street, Mtskheta. (Photo A. Muhranoff, 2011).jpg|150px]] [[File:Georgia Jvari monastery IMG 9345 2070.jpg|150px]] |[[Mtskheta-Mtianeti]]
{{coord|41|51|N|44|43|E|region:GE_type:landmark|name=Historical Monuments of Mtskheta}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1994 |The historic churches of Mtskheta, former capital of Georgia, are outstanding examples of medieval religious architecture in the Caucasus. They show the high artistic and cultural level attained by this ancient kingdom. The classification includes two of Georgia's most ancient religious structures: the [[Svetitskhoveli]] (Cathedral of the Living Pillar) and the [[Jvari Monastery]] (Monastery of the Cross), as well as the historical area of Mtskheta in which the two are situated. The monuments trace their origin to the dawn of Christianity in Georgia in the first half of the first millennium A.D. and were judged by UNESCO to be a testament of "the high artistic and cultural level attained by this ancient kingdom." |- ! scope="row"| [[Upper Svaneti]] | [[File:Mestia. General view.jpg|150x150px|alt=Stone towers in a mountain landscape]] |[[Mestia District]], [[Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti]]
{{coord|42|54|59|N|43|0|41|E|region:GE_type:landmark|name=Upper Svaneti}} | Cultural:
(iv)(v) | {{convert|1.06|ha|disp=b|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|19|ha|disp=b|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1996 |These upper lands of Georgia's alpine region of Svaneti were recognized by UNESCO as an "exceptional example of mountain scenery with medieval-type villages and tower-houses", which were often family-built and served to protect against invaders for centuries. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/709 |title=Upper Svaneti |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=17 Aug 2011}} |} ===Tentative list=== In addition to sites inscribed on the World Heritage list, member states can maintain a list of tentative sites that they may consider for nomination. Nominations for the World Heritage list are only accepted if the site was previously listed on the tentative list.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/ |title=Tentative Lists |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=7 October 2010}} As of 2018, Georgia maintains fifteen properties on its tentative list:{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=ge |title=Tentative List – Georgia |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=6 August 2018}} * [[Alaverdi Monastery|Alaverdi Cathedral]] * [[Ananuri]] * [[Kolkheti National Park|Colchis Wetlands and Forests]] * [[David Gareja monastery complex|David Gareji Monasteries and Hermitage]] * [[Dmanisi]] Hominid Archaeological Site * [[Gremi]] Church of Archangels and Royal Tower * [[Kvetera Church]] * [[Tusheti|Mta-Tusheti]] * [[Nikortsminda Cathedral|Nicortsminda Cathedral]] * [[Samtavisi Cathedral]] * [[Shatili]] * [[Tbilisi]] Historic District * [[Uplistsikhe]] Cave Town * [[Vani]] * [[Vardzia]]-[[Khertvisi]] ==See also== *[[Tourism in Georgia]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commonscat|World Heritage Sites in Georgia}} * [http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ge UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Georgia] {{World Heritage Sites in Georgia}} {{Lists of World Heritage Sites in Europe}} {{Lists of World Heritage Sites}} {{Georgia (country) topics}} [[Category:Lists of World Heritage Sites|Georgia]] [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Georgia (country)|*]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Georgia (country)|World Heritage Sites]]
